8.10.19  10:32 pm   what's your opinion on wireless ear buds

      latency hasn't come down enough for it to be good enough for things requiring instant response to user actions. i.e. music production, or phone conversations, or any type of game where it's important to hear an instant sound response to something you did. they're awesome as long as you're just consuming audio tracks (listening to music, not interacting with it) because once the song starts (half second late) it doesn't matter if the whole song is a half second late. Even video watching is ok, because most video players are smart enough to buffer it right so the vid syncs right with the audio. But if you're recording music, you're still looking at at least a 200ms latency. can't play an instrument that way. And this is not good for intimate phone calls either, because as it is, in the digital world, all cell phone calls have about half second delay (or more) already. And this gets worse when you're doing international, or internet calling. wireless ear phones will add at least quarter second delay on top of that. however, besides all that, it is truly awesome to have no wires. but i'd say the latency probably isn't down enough to discontinue the headphone jack just yet

8.4.19  12:50 pm   Regarding your AppleScript issue: I've had trouble getting my GUI actions to be recorded by pointing and clicking with a mouse. I DO get the results I want by outlining the keyboard shortcuts for the specific app. Good luck!

     actually, the main point of this particular operation is to have solutions for those strange situations where there is absolutely no keyboard shortcut, nor menu item (if it was a menu item i could make a keyboard shortcut for it, but some software likes to go to more advanced planes of inaccessibility)

      AppleScript keycodes: https://eastmanreference.com/complete-list-of-applescript-key-codes

Example used with my video editing software:

tell application "System Events"
key code 0 using {command down} # select all
        delay 0.5
        key code 44 using {shift down, command down} # select top menu
delay 0.5
repeat 3 times # arrow left over to Action menu
key code 123
end repeat
delay 1
repeat 7 times # arrow down to Templates

html:
7.25.19  9:12 pm   7.23.19  9:15 pm    Hey thanks for the response bill, I figured that was the best and tried laying down a temp track, it just felt a little stale compared to the excitement of getting ideas for first time in a while and how good they sounded to me. is this just me being impatient to record and i should wait, or would experimenting with recording the guitar, adjusting it to tempo and then recording a final track of real time guitar?


embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201907232115

7.23.19  9:15 pm   I've got some songs I wrote on guitar and I want to record them to record more of my music, but I feel stuck unless I'm playing on my guitar. Is it better to record the guitar and build from there or try to lay a groundwork and then overdub it for stable rhythm?

      it's going to be a very different activity, playing/singing as a 1 person live performer (guitar), vs. designing an arrangement. both processes can be very rewarding, but they're totally different. if you're doing an arrangement i would not recommend starting with your normal solo guitar performance. if you're working alone, i would strongly recommend using a click and doing percussion first. then do temp instruments, then temp vocal, then go back and re-build the instrumental arrangement, then finally re-do the vocal, then maybe touch up the instruments then maybe touch up the vocal. where as, on the other hand, if you'd rather capture the solo singer-songwriter/guitar performance, i would suggest capturing as much room noise as you can

html:
6.30.19  11:21 pm   6.28.19  5:10 am First I'd like to say in regards to 6.28.19  5:10 am , I think my core confusion was that more=better when voicing (and then being too indecisive to know what to cut off for fear of dropping out anything "good" by dropping anything out and taking more=better to the extreme of 4 notes per hand for beef purposes, and somehow perceiving the chord root a third below where it was supposed to be for one of them, perhaps because i was voicing stuff so high that I didnt have a grounding bass sound, not trying to make excuses, just trying to pinpoint my mistakes and the core belief behind to more efficiently improve.

Anyways back to chord talk.I really like that bass 2 octaves below, I find i rarely try going around those ranges when playing in my midi keyboard and it can really do a loooot to beef up smaller chords that may be playin g on rig ht hand. For some reason when I do go that low I usually double that octave but through listening to these clear examples i can see how it can actually unbeef the lowest note.

      Because if the patch im playing with say has any vibrato, tremolo, or even chorusing or other dsp, by doubling the octave you wouldn't necessarily get that extra punch at the desired frequencies because there'd be way more noise (noise as in many more frequencies besides the fundamental, not really all-frequencies-noise) because of the nature of timbre and that could muddy up the low end.

      I just realized my 61key midi keyboard doesnt go below c(65).

      When trying out the stuff you mentioned i put it an octave down and will be able to jam at a happier harmonic space.

      Going with your Ab 52 example going with chord starting at Bb233, I like doing Bb C Eb G

      and trying the second as u suggested with Bb 58 and C D F starting at middle c. Do you think you stray away from also playing Bb right below middle c wit h your r ight hand because of the most reasonable note to fit in a happy harmonic place within the context of the current notes is the root and its already in the bass?

      Trying to reason out when 3 notes might do a better work than 4 (again fighting against my now aware bias towards more=better).

     I thought i might add some more chords to those 2 to practice and get your thoughts with a bigger context so this is what i came up with to get a complete harmonic idea. https://imgur.com/Dx5oEck

     Now, i'm happy with all but my first chord, the thing about the first chord is that I have an alternative way, by removing the Bb.

      I like both but this is when my indecisiveness/whelm for possibilities/overthinking starts.  

     I like the 4 notes on right hand as its the first measure and maybe it reinforces the one, but at the same time i think Bb could be better off not there for several contexts. To have a clear one, lets say we're singing never gonna give you up's f irst ver se.

       I also like Bb but no C. these would be the 3 variations im deciding between: https://imgur.com/3gKUMvN.

      I think it would make more sense to remove the Bb and keep C on the first chord and leave the 4 chords like this: https://imgur.com/mGJT4lj

      but tbh i find it hard to decide mostly because of indecisiveness and fomo on the other possibilities.

     Would those last voicings make the most sense to you?

      I really like the other 2 voicings but I'm not 100% sure of my choice of voicing it as Cmin with Ab bass (to make a Abmaj7) I was wondering to what degree would context have to change for those 3 to be usable or the most optimal for specific contextual situations in your opinion? Is my choice the most appropriate for a Rickroll reharm/voicing?

     
I hope im not misusing/abusing the questions page. Highly appreciate your input and you taking your time.


embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201906280510

6.28.19  5:10 am   6.26.19  7:39 pm when i say G-Bb-D-F-Bb-C-D-F I really mean a voicing made of those notes bottom up, not each chord per letter.

     i know

      I was gonna write g-bb-f-d-bb-c-d-f but b for flat with non capital letter felt b for ti felt weird. I dont know if that makes more or less sense. And i did call Gb7 something wrong. I think its the Gmin7 with a "Bb add9" on top. so really a Gmin7 add11 with doubled 5th and 7th,  but revisitting it it should be a Bb something, as so the F something should really be a Ab something. and yes i do agree these are separate universes, but i wont let that excuse me from doing things in a perceivably wrong way(regardless of how thick i want my supersaws to sound). I get too sidetracked for beefiness that I may be overdoing the voicings and cluttering the arrangement (and missing the tonal center). Highly truly appreciate you taking your time to go over my rant and bring obje ctivity.   Now I have another point of view(and way more experienced) on my voicing approach or atleast cataloguing.  Sometimes it feels like im working on a vacuum but im super grateful and lucky to be able to bounce these things with a way more experienced skillster to atleast have a sense of where the needle might be pointing as opposed to letting my subjectivenes or missfocus from sidetracking me into a least-ideal place. I hope my follow up made more sense and had less mistakes at essential points. . So the 2 chord thing i was describing once i take your advice into consideration would be something like Ab bass (the F at the bottom was really unnecesary, its really some sort of Ab) with right hand doing g-bb-eb, and then going to G bass with f-g-bb-d on right hand.

     ah, much more comfortable

     How do you chose what to leave out when using many tensions on chords?

     experience, knowing the songs, knowing what sounds happen when you use different combinations of notes. the only way to really learn is to spend a lot of time with the instrument, a lot of time with songs, and general life experience. you will even find yourself gaining experience in stores, when you hear something on the radio

      Or it's a feel-along excercise with the theory behind the played voicings being an afterthought to analyze what was done? Upon yet ano ther revision my last version would be Ab (207.65) and on right hand g(392)-bb-c=eb which would translate to Abmaj7add9, and then for second chord Bb on bass (233) and then on right hand f(349)-bb-c-d. which would be a Bbadd9. Does it sound like a more balanced voicing?

     that seems great but very much on the high side. your bass notes are around middle C. this is cool, but if you are generally in the meat of the arrangement, your bass notes are going to be an octave lower (probably 2) and the right hand parts would be maybe half an octave lower. i'd say a nice happy range for your first chord (speaking in Hz again, cuz it's the only way to truly say which octaves we're using) Ab 52, and chord would start from Bb233 and up. a good range for the other one would be Bb 58, and C D F starting from middle C and up.

      I did have a weird keys patch where i was jamming with it but going to a normal keyboard sound makes it clearer to hear what im doing instead of letting the reverb disguise the sound. It seems like by your description your instinct would be to go for bass on left and guide tones (3rd and 7th) on right and then alter from there? 

     that's always cool, if you don't know the song yet and specifically what it needs where. also it's good to practice shuffling the range around so the chord/harmony generally is situated around the middle C range. that's just where all the harmony wants to be. i think the more music you check out, the more you will find that that's almost always where the actual harmony is taking place. you may have many instruments helping out, but there are never actually that many different notes being played. the harmonic content is really usually in the middle C range and slightly above. that's just something that i've found over time. when you hear a dense arrangement with a lot of instruments, i think you'd be amazed to find out that there still aren't that many different notes being played, there will be a lot of instruments playing the same notes (layering)
